'''Joscelyn Eve Stoker'''<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.findmypast.com/post84BMDSearchStart.action?&submit=1&route=X&searchType=B&fromYear=1986&toYear=1988&forename1=Jocelyn&surname=Stoker |title=Births – England & Wales 1984–2006 |publisher=findmypast.com |access-date=3 May 2008}}</ref> (born 11 April 1987), known professionally as '''Joss Stone''', is an English singer, songwriter and actress. She rose to prominence in late 2003 with her multi-platinum debut album, ''[[The Soul Sessions]]'', which made the 2004 [[Mercury Prize]] shortlist. Her second album, ''[[Mind Body & Soul]]'' (2004), topped the [[UK Albums Chart]] and spawned the top-ten single "[[You Had Me]]", Stone's most successful single on the [[UK Singles Chart]] to date. Both the album and single received one nomination at the [[47th Grammy Awards|2005 Grammy Awards]], while Stone herself was nominated for [[Grammy Award for Best New Artist|Best New Artist]], and in an annual [[BBC]] poll of music critics, [[Sound of 2004]],<ref name="Sound of 2004">{{cite news | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/music/3369355.stm | title=Sound of 2004 |publisher=BBC | date=9 January 2004 | access-date=24 March 2010 | location=London}}</ref> was ranked fifth as a predicted breakthrough act of 2004.<ref name="Sound of 2004"/> She became the youngest British female singer to top the UK Albums Chart. Stone's third album, ''[[Introducing Joss Stone]]'', released in March 2007, achieved gold record status by the [[Recording Industry Association of America]] (RIAA) and yielded the second-ever highest debut for a British female solo artist on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]], and became Stone's first top-five album in the US.

She released her fourth album, ''[[Colour Me Free!]]'', in 2009, which reached the top 10 on ''Billboard''. Stone released her fifth album, ''[[LP1 (Joss Stone album)|LP1]]'', in 2011, which reached the top 10 on ''Billboard''. Throughout her career, Stone has sold 15 million records worldwide, establishing herself as one of the best-selling soul artists of the 2000s, and the best-selling British artists of her time.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jossstone.com/lp1.html|title=LP1|publisher=jossstone.com|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110609080818/http://www.jossstone.com/lp1.html|archive-date=9 June 2011|access-date=14 May 2012|url-status=dead}}</ref> Her first three albums have sold over 2,722,000 copies in the US, while her first two albums have sold over 2 million copies in the UK.

Stone has earned several awards including two [[Brit Awards]] and one [[Grammy Award]] out of five nominations. She made her film acting debut in 2006 with the fantasy adventure film ''[[Eragon (film)|Eragon]]'', and made her television debut portraying [[Anne of Cleves]] in the [[Showtime (TV network)|Showtime]] series ''[[The Tudors]]'' in 2009.<ref name="tudors">{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/musicNews/idUSN0525768620080805 |title=Joss Stone playing homely wife in "Tudors" |access-date=5 August 2008 |last=Andreeva |first=Nellie |date=5 August 2008 |work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |agency=Reuters}}</ref> Stone was the youngest woman on the 2006 ''[[Sunday Times Rich List]]''—an annual list of the UK's wealthiest people—with £6 million.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://uk.movies.yahoo.com/08122006/5/harry-potter-joss-stone-richest-uk-teens-0.html |title=Harry Potter and Joss Stone richest UK teens |access-date=2 February 2008 |date=8 December 2006 |publisher=[[Yahoo! ==Early life==
Joscelyn Eve Stoker was born on 11 April 1987 at [[Buckland Hospital]] in [[Dover]], [[Kent]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://doversoul.tripod.com/id64.html |title=Dover's Soul Sensation Joss Stone |access-date=5 February 2008 |date=16 October 2004 |work=Devon Soul |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070731013102/http://doversoul.tripod.com/id64.html |archive-date=31 July 2007}}</ref> and spent her teenage years in [[Ashill, Devon|Ashill]], a small village near [[Cullompton]] in Devon. She is the third of four children born to Wendy (née Skillin) and Richard Stoker.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/article/0,,18909-1243965,00.html |title=Joss Stone |access-date=27 January 2007 |last=Jackson |first=Alan |date=4 September 2004 |work=The Times |location=London}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Radar%3A+JOSS+IN+999+DASH%3B+Atlantic+trip+to+be+with+sick+grandad.-a0133166091 |title=Radar: JOSS IN 999 DASH; Atlantic trip to be with sick grandad. – Free Online Library |publisher=Thefreelibrary.com |date=12 June 2005 |access-date=4 June 2014}}</ref> Her father owns a fruit and [[nut (fruit)|nut]] import–export business;<ref name="bio">{{cite web |url=http://www.notablebiographies.com/newsmakers2/2006-Ra-Z/Stone-Joss.html |title=Joss Stone Biography |access-date=30 January 2009 |last=Frick |first=Lisa |work=Notable Biographies}}</ref> her mother worked as Stone's manager until October 2004. Stone made her first public appearance at the [[Uffculme School|Uffculme Comprehensive School]]—which she attended<ref>{{cite news |url=http://arts.guardian.co.uk/features/story/0,,1267463,00.html |title=The Guardian profile: Joss Stone |access-date=11 May 2007 |last=Sullivan |first=Caroline |date=23 July 2004 |work=The Guardian |location=London}}</ref>—in [[Uffculme]], Devon, with a cover version of [[Jackie Wilson]]'s 1957 song "[[Reet Petite]]".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.onlineseats.com/joss-stone-tickets/index.asp |title=Joss Stone Tickets |access-date=11 May 2007 |publisher=OnlineSeats.com |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070503033058/http://www.onlineseats.com/joss-stone-tickets/index.asp |archive-date=3 May 2007 |url-status=dead}}</ref> Stone has [[dyslexia]] and left school at age sixteen with only three [[General Certificate of Secondary Education|GCSE]] qualifications. "It wasn't that I was stupid. I'm just a little bit [[dyslexic]] and I wasn't very academic. I'm more artistic", she says.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://ca.askmen.com/gossip/joss-stone/joss-stone-insists--im-not-thick.html |title=Joss Stone insists – 'I'm not thick' |access-date=16 August 2007 |date=16 October 2004 |publisher=[[AskMen.com]] |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930203659/http://ca.askmen.com/gossip/joss-stone/joss-stone-insists--im-not-thick.html |archive-date=30 September 2007}}</ref>

Stone grew up listening to a wide variety of music including 1960s and 1970s American R&B and soul music performed by such artists as [[Dusty Springfield]] and [[Aretha Franklin]]. As a result, she developed a soulful style of singing like her idols. "My first CD that I owned was ''Aretha Franklin: [[Greatest Hits (Aretha Franklin album)|Greatest Hits]]''. And I saw the advert on TV and it was just like little clips of her songs. I had no idea who she was—I was only like 10 so. I said, 'Oh yeah, that looks really good', so I wrote it down and I said to my mum, 'Can I have that for Christmas?' So she told my friend Dennis, who always gets me good music anyway, and he got that for me. So that was one of my first albums that I loved."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.cnn.com/2003/SHOWBIZ/Music/12/31/mroom.stone/ |title=Joss Stone takes on soul |access-date=15 June 2008 |date=2 January 2004 |publisher=CNN}}</ref> She would later tell [[MTV News]]: "I kind of clicked into soul music more than anything else because of the vocals. You've got to have good vocals to sing soul music and I always liked it ever since I was little."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/yhif/stone_joss/ |title=You Hear It First – Joss Stone |access-date=15 November 2007 |last=D'Angelo |first=Joe |publisher=[[MTV News]] |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111105113130/http://www.mtv.com/news/yhif/stone_joss/ |archive-date= 5 November 2011}}</ref>

==Career==

===2001–2003: Beginnings and ''The Soul Sessions''===
[[File:Joss Stone.jpg|thumb|Stone performing live in Milan in 2005, during ''Mind, Body & Soul Sessions Tour'']]
In 2001, at the age of thirteen, Stone auditioned for the [[BBC Television]] talent show, ''[[Star for a Night (British TV series)|Star for a Night]]'' in London, singing Franklin's 1968 [[Gerry Goffin|Goffin]]-[[Carole King|King]] hit "[[(You Make Me Feel Like) A Natural Woman]]" and [[Whitney Houston]]'s 1999 single, "[[It's Not Right but It's Okay]]".<ref name="bio"/> After passing her audition, she sang [[Donna Summer]]'s  "[[On the Radio (Donna Summer song)|On the Radio]]" for the broadcast, and eventually won the contest. She also appeared on and won ''Steps to the Stars'' (a TV programme hosted by H & Claire of the group [[Steps (group)|Steps]]).<ref name="bio"/> Stone then performed on a charity show, where she drew the attention of the Boilerhouse Boys, composed of London-based producers Andy Dean and Ben Wolfe, who contacted [[S-Curve Records]] founder and CEO, [[Steve Greenberg (record producer)|Steve Greenberg]] in December 2001 telling him that "they had just heard the greatest singer they'd ever heard from their country."<ref name="indielondon">{{cite web |url=http://www.indielondon.co.uk/music/mu_joss_stone_bio.html |title=The lowdown on Dover's soul sensation, Joss Stone |access-date=15 November 2007 |last=Foley |first=Jack |publisher=IndieLondon.co.uk}}</ref> In early 2002, Greenberg flew Stone to New York for an audition, in which she sang to backing tracks of classic soul songs: [[Otis Redding]]'s 1968 "[[(Sittin' On) The Dock of the Bay]]", [[Gladys Knight & the Pips]]' 1973 "[[Midnight Train to Georgia]]", and Franklin's "(You Make Me Feel Like) A Natural Woman";<ref name="indielondon"/> Greenberg instantly signed her to his label.<ref name="bio"/>

After being signed by [[S-Curve Records]], her US market album was released by S-Curve Records and in the international market her album was released by [[EMI Music]]. Stone flew to Miami and Philadelphia to start work on her debut album, ''[[The Soul Sessions]]'', released on 16 September 2003. She collaborated with people with solid credentials in the Miami soul scene such as [[Betty Wright]], [[Latimore (musician)|Benny Latimore]], [[Timmy Thomas]] and [[Willie Hale|Little Beaver]] as well as contemporary acts [[Angie Stone]] and [[the Roots]]. The album, produced by [[Steve Greenberg (record producer)|Steve Greenberg]], Mike Mangini and [[Betty Wright]], consists of little-known soul tracks by Franklin, [[Laura Lee (singer-songwriter)|Laura Lee]], [[Bettye Swann]] and others. Released in late 2003, it reached the top five on the [[UK Albums Chart]] as well as the top forty of the US [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]] chart. The lead single, "[[Fell in Love with a Boy]]", a reworking of [[the White Stripes]]' 2001 "[[Fell in Love with a Girl]]", reached the top 20 of the [[UK Singles Chart]], as did the second single, a cover version of Sugar Billy's 1974 song "[[Super Duper Love (Are You Diggin' on Me)]]". The album eventually went triple platinum by the [[British Phonographic Industry]] in mid-April 2005<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bpi.co.uk/platinum/platinumright.asp?rq=search_plat&r_id=32181 |title=BPI Certified Awards – The Soul Sessions |access-date=9 February 2008 |work=[[British Phonographic Industry|BPI]] |date=15 April 2005 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080220133205/http://www.bpi.co.uk/platinum/platinumRight.asp?rq=search_plat |archive-date=20 February 2008}}</ref> and gold by the [[Recording Industry Association of America]] in late March 2004.<ref name="riaa">{{cite web |url=https://www.riaa.com/goldandplatinumdata.php?table=SEARCH_RESULTS&artist=Joss%20Stone&perPage=25 |title=Gold & Platinum |access-date=9 February 2008 |work=[[Recording Industry Association of America]]}}</ref>

===2004–2006: ''Mind Body & Soul'' and film debut===
[[File:Jossstone07.jpg|thumb|right|upright|Joss Stone in 2007]]
After achieving critical acclaim with ''The Soul Sessions'', Stone worked on new material, and recorded her second album, ''[[Mind Body & Soul]]'', which was released on 28 September 2004, produced by the same team as her first album. She called the album her real debut.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.soundgenerator.com/viewArticle.cfm?ArticleID=3973 |archive-url=https://archive.today/20110811025734/http://www.soundgenerator.com/viewArticle.cfm?ArticleID=3973 |url-status=dead |archive-date=11 August 2011 |title=Joss Stone Prepares To Deliver "Mind Body & Soul" |access-date=7 April 2008 |date=3 August 2004 |publisher=Soundgenerator.com}}</ref> It debuted at No. one in the UK, breaking the record for the youngest female ever to top the UK Albums Chart,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/music/3739464.stm |title=US chart success for Joss Stone |access-date=16 February 2008 |date=13 October 2004 |publisher=BBC News | location=London}}</ref> and just missed the top ten of the US [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]] after peaking at No. 11. The lead single, "[[You Had Me]]", became her biggest hit to date when it rose to No. 9 in the UK. Follow-up singles "[[Right to Be Wrong]]" and "[[Spoiled (song)|Spoiled]]" both made the top 40, and "[[Don't Cha Wanna Ride]]", the top 20. "Spoiled" landed just outside the top 50 of US [[Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs]], peaking at No. 54. In early September 2005, ''Mind, Body & Soul'' was certified triple platinum by the BPI<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bpi.co.uk/platinum/platinumright.asp?rq=search_plat&r_id=32303 |title=BPI Certified Awards – Mind, Body & Soul |access-date=10 February 2008 |work=BPI |date=9 September 2005 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080220133205/http://www.bpi.co.uk/platinum/platinumRight.asp?rq=search_plat |archive-date=20 February 2008}}</ref> and platinum by the RIAA.<ref name="riaa"/>

In April 2004, Stone performed during the [[VH1]]'s benefit concert [[VH1 Divas|Divas Live 2004]] alongside [[Ashanti (entertainer)|Ashanti]], [[Cyndi Lauper]], [[Gladys Knight]], [[Jessica Simpson]] and [[Patti LaBelle]], in support of the Save the Music Foundation. Stone joined [[Band Aid 20]] on 14 November 2004 in benefit of [[Sudan]]'s troubled [[Darfur]] region. The group, which included [[Coldplay]] lead singer [[Chris Martin]] and U2 lead singer [[Bono]], re-recorded the 1984 song "[[Do They Know It's Christmas?]]", written by [[Band Aid (band)|Band Aid]] organisers [[Bob Geldof]] and [[Midge Ure]]. Stone, who was born two years after the release of the original single, was not initially aware of who Bob Geldof was,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/totp/news/top5/2005/05/10/19220.shtml |title=Top of the Pops – Top 5 – Lord of the Blings |access-date=9 January 2007 |last=Cooke |first=Matthew |date=10 May 2005 |publisher=BBC}}</ref> with media reporting that she repeatedly referred to him as Bob [[Gandalf]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.pressureworks.org/frontline/features/LIVE8_2.html |title=LIVE8: the backlash |access-date=9 January 2007 |date=7 June 2005 |publisher=PressureWorks.com |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20051222100202/http://www.pressureworks.org/frontline/features/LIVE8_2.html |archive-date=22 December 2005 |url-status=dead}}</ref> Despite some criticism, the single became the UK's biggest-selling single of 2004<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bpi.co.uk/pdf/BestSellingSingles01-05.pdf |title=The UK's Best Selling Singles 2004 |access-date=9 January 2007 |work=BPI |archive-url =https://web.archive.org/web/20070930230017/http://www.bpi.co.uk/pdf/BestSellingSingles01-05.pdf <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archive-date = 30 September 2007}}</ref> as well as the 2004 [[Christmas number-one single]].

At the [[2005 BRIT Awards]], Stone won for British Female Solo Artist and British Urban Act—entering the ''[[Guinness World Records]]'' as the youngest BRIT Award solo winner at age seventeen, and was nominated for British Breakthrough Act.<ref name="brits">{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/music/4162591.stm |title=Brits 2005: The winners |access-date=17 February 2009 |date=9 February 2005 |publisher=BBC News | location=London}}</ref> She also received a nomination for Best UK Act of the Year at the 2005 [[MOBO Awards]],<ref name="mobo2005">{{cite web |url=http://www.mobo.net/?page=455 |title=MOBO Awards – Nominees 2005 |access-date=17 February 2009 |publisher=MOBO.net |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090417044708/http://www.mobo.net/?page=455 |archive-date=17 April 2009}}</ref> as well as three nominations for the [[47th Grammy Awards|2005 Grammy Awards]]—[[Grammy Award for Best New Artist|Best New Artist]], [[Grammy Award for Best Female Pop Vocal Performance|Best Female Pop Vocal Performance]] for "You Had Me", and [[Grammy Award for Best Pop Vocal Album|Best Pop Vocal Album]] for ''Mind Body & Soul'',<ref name="bio"/> where she sang with rock performer [[Melissa Etheridge]], in tribute to blues-rock singer [[Janis Joplin]]. Their performance of "Cry Baby/[[Piece of My Heart]]" was released as a single, and through the aid of strong digital download sales, became Stone's first single to enter the US [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]], when it debuted and peaked at No. 32 the week of 2 April 2005.<ref>{{cite magazine |url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/63581/50-cent-nets-a-fourth-top-10-hit |title=50 Cent Nets A Fourth Top 10 Hit |access-date=3 November 2008 |last=Whitmire |first=Margo |date=24 March 2005 |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]}}</ref>

[[File:Chris and joss.jpg|thumb|left|Stone with then BBC Radio 2 presenter [[Chris Evans (presenter)|Chris Evans]] in 2005]]

|url=http://www.andpop.com/article/4065 |title=Gap Replaces Sarah Jessica Parker with Joss Stone |access-date=17 June 2007 |last=Gonshor |first=Adam |date=23 March 2005 |work=andPOP |url-status=dead |url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/showbiz/a22942/joss-stone-not-axed-by-gap.html |title=Joss Stone not axed by GAP |access-date=17 June 2007 |last=Green |first=Kris |date=25 July 2005 |work=[[Digital with [[Donna Summer]], and 1977's "[[Hot Legs]]" with [[Rod Stewart]] at "Save the Music: A Concert to Benefit the VH1 Save the Music Foundation", in benefit of [[VH1]]'s Save the Music Foundation.<ref name="vh1">{{cite web |url=http://news.sawf.org/Entertainment/1025.aspx |archive-url=https://archive.today/20130113090333/http://news.sawf.org/Entertainment/1025.aspx |url-status=dead London. Stone was an opening act for [[the Rolling Stones]] during their 2005 [[A Bigger Bang Tour|A Bigger Bang tour]].<ref>{{Cite news|date=28 July 2005|title=Stones roll back with a 'Bang'|pages=437|work=The Miami Herald|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/78953699/stones-roll-back-with-a-bang/|access-date=4 June 2021}}</ref>

Stone performed a [[medley (music)|medley]] of "[[It's a Man's Man's Man's World|It's a Man's World]]" and "[[Papa's Got a Brand New Bag]]" with [[James Brown]] on [[BBC One]]'s chat show ''[[Friday Night with Jonathan Ross]]'' on 1 July 2005.<ref name="jamesbrown">{{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/pressoffice/pressreleases/stories/2005/06_june/29/ross.shtml |title=James Brown and Joss Stone rip it up with Jonathan Ross |access-date=3 May 2008 |date=29 June 2005 |publisher=BBC}}</ref> Stone collaborated with [[jazz]] pianist [[Herbie Hancock]] and [[blues]] singer-guitarist [[Jonny Lang]] on a cover of [[U2]]'s 1988 song "[[When Love Comes to Town]]" for Hancock's 2005 album ''[[Possibilities (album)|Possibilities]]''. That same year, Stone was featured along with [[Sean Paul]] on [[Carlos Santana|Santana]]'s "[[Cry Baby Cry (Santana song)|Cry Baby Cry]]", and worked on a remake of [[Patti LaBelle]]'s 1985 song "[[Stir It Up (Patti LaBelle song)|Stir It Up]]" for the soundtrack to the [[Walt Disney Pictures|Disney]] animated film ''[[Chicken Little (2005 film)|Chicken Little]]''.<ref name="elle">{{cite web |url=http://www.elle.com/coverfullstory/7685/joss-stone-page2.html |title=Joss Stone – ELLE |access-date=19 May 2007 |last=Dunn |first=Jancee |work=[[ELLE]] |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070525223021/http://www.elle.com/coverfullstory/7685/joss-stone-page2.html |archive-date=25 May 2007}}</ref> She also collaborated with [[Lemar]] in 2006 on his third studio album, ''[[The Truth About Love (Lemar album)|The Truth About Love]]'', on the track "Anniversary".

On 5 February 2006, Stone joined [[Stevie Wonder]], [[India.Arie]], and John Legend during the [[Super Bowl XL]] pre-game ceremonies to perform a medley of Wonder's hits. Three days later, on 8 February, on the night of the [[48th Grammy Awards|2006 Grammy Awards]], she helped perform a medley of [[Sly & the Family Stone]]'s hits alongside Legend, [[Ciara]], [[Maroon 5]], [[will.i.am]], [[Robert Randolph and the Family Band|Robert Randolph]], [[Steven Tyler]] and [[Joe Perry (musician)|Joe Perry]]. Stone made her film debut in the fantasy adventure film ''[[Eragon (film)|Eragon]]'' (based on the [[Eragon|2003 novel of the same name]] by [[Christopher Paolini]]), directed by [[Stefen Fangmeier]] and released on 15 December 2006, playing the fortune teller [[characters in the Inheritance Trilogy#Angela|Angela]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mtv.com/movies/news/articles/1547720/story.jhtml |title=Joss Stone Gets in Touch With Witchy Side For Film Debut In 'Eragon' |access-date=3 May 2008 |last=Carroll |first=Larry |date=12 December 2006 |work=MTV Movie News}}</ref> At the [[49th Grammy Awards|2007 Grammy Awards]], Stone shared the award for [[Grammy Award for Best R&B Performance by a Duo or Group with Vocals|Best R&B Performance by a Duo or Group with Vocals]] for her collaboration with [[John Legend]] and [[Van Hunt]] on their 2005 cover of [[Sly & the Family Stone]]'s 1971 chart-topper "[[Family Affair (Sly & the Family Stone song)|Family Affair]]".<ref name="grammy2007">{{cite web|url=http://www.grammy.com/GRAMMY_Awards/49th_Show/list.aspx#06 |title=49th Annual Grammy Awards Winners List |access-date=30 January 2009 |publisher=National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences |url-status=dead |archive-url=http://webarchive.loc.gov/all/20061220160454/http://www.grammy.com/GRAMMY_Awards/49th_Show/list.aspx |archive-date=20 December 2006}}</ref>

===2007–2008: ''Introducing Joss Stone''===
[[File:MMVA2007 Joss Stone 3A2V0205.jpg|thumb|right|upright|Stone at the Much Music Video Awards in 2007]]
Stone caused controversy at the [[2007 BRIT Awards]] ceremony on 14 February 2007 while presenting the award for British Male Solo Artist (won by [[James Morrison (singer)|James Morrison]]).<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xJWO5CLo4zI | archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/varchive/youtube/20211109/xJWO5CLo4zI| archive-date=2021-11-09 | url-status=live|title=James Morrison wins British Male presented by Joss Stone – BRIT Awards 2007 |website=[[YouTube]] |access-date=23 April 2013}}{{cbignore}}</ref> Speaking in an [[American English|American accent]], she circled the podium and gave a speech about [[Robbie Williams]], who had been the target of earlier jokes made by host [[Russell Brand]]. Williams had been reported as going into [[drug rehabilitation|rehabilitation]] that same week. As her speech continued, she made remarks about Brand, implying that he was heading for rehabilitation himself (while singing a passage of [[Amy Winehouse]]'s hit "[[Rehab (Amy Winehouse song)|Rehab]]").<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.contactmusic.com/news.nsf/article/joss%20brits%20dont%20like%20me_1049939 |title=Joss: BRITs Don't Like Me |access-date=31 December 2007 |date=14 November 2007 |publisher=ContactMusic.com}}</ref> In response to the British media's reaction, Stone responded, "At the end of the day, I don't give a fuck if people have a problem with my accent. That's all I can say about it. The words I say do not change. If the way that it sounds is skew-wiff and you don't like it, don't listen. I'm not being a cruel person by sounding a different way. And I can't help it. I've been [in America working] since I was, like, 14."<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/joss-stone-england-doesnt-like-me-any-more-771027.html |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/archive/20220617/https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/joss-stone-england-doesnt-like-me-any-more-771027.html |archive-date=17 June 2022 |url-access=subscription |url-status=live |title=Joss Stone: 'England doesn't like me any more' |access-date=13 March 2008 |date=20 January 2008 |work=The Independent |location=London}}</ref> Stone later claimed that her record label cancelled all her upcoming press appearances to publicise her upcoming third album as a result of the backlash.<ref>[http://metro.co.uk/2009/11/03/joss-stone-it-was-just-an-accent-528822/ Joss Stone: It was just an accent] – Metro, 29 July 2009</ref>

[[File:Joss Stone Heart Truth5.jpg|thumb|left|upright|Stone walking at the Heart Truth charity fashion show 2008]]
Stone began work on her third studio album, ''[[Introducing Joss Stone]]'', at [[Compass Point Studios]] in [[Nassau, Bahamas|Nassau]], Bahamas, in May 2006.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.psychopedia.com/dailynews/2006/10/my_town_barbadossoul_princess.html |title=Soul Princess Joss Stone's Favorite Isle |access-date=9 March 2007 |date=13 October 2006 |work=psychoPEDIA |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927115814/http://www.psychopedia.com/dailynews/2006/10/my_town_barbadossoul_princess.html |archive-date=27 September 2007}}</ref> Released on 12 March 2007, the album was coordinated by A&R [[Chris Anokute]], produced by [[Raphael Saadiq]], and included collaborations with [[Lauryn Hill]], [[Common (rapper)|Common]], and [[Joi (singer)|Joi]].<ref name="hitquarters.com">{{cite web |url=http://www.hitquarters.com/index.php3?page=intrview/opar/intrview_Chris_Anokute_Interview.html |title=Interview With Chris Anokute |publisher=[[HitQuarters]]|date=18 October 2010 |access-date=26 October 2010}}</ref> [[Virgin Records]] describes the album as "an electrifying mix of warm vintage soul, 1970s-style R&B, [[Motown Records|Motown]] [[girl group|girl-group]] [[harmony|harmonies]], and [[hip hop music|hip-hop]] [[groove (music)|grooves]]".<ref name="harp">{{cite web|url=http://harpmagazine.com/news/detail.cfm?article=10828 |title=Joss Stone Discusses New Album, Due March 20, With HARP |access-date=27 January 2007 |last=Konrad |first=Ashley |date=18 January 2007 |work=[[Harp (magazine)|Harp]] |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070629114523/http://www.harpmagazine.com/news/detail.cfm?article=10828 |archive-date=29 June 2007}}</ref> Stone herself describes it as "truly me. That's why I'm calling it ''Introducing Joss Stone''. These are my words, and this is who I am as an artist."<ref name="harp"/> She also revealed on ''[[The Tavis Smiley Show]]'' that her break-up with Beau Dozier was a source of inspiration while writing ''Introducing Joss Stone''.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.pbs.org/kcet/tavissmiley/archive/200703/20070319_stone.html |title=Tavis Smiley Archives – Joss Stone |access-date=23 March 2007 |date=19 March 2007 |work=[[PBS]]}}</ref> The album debuted and peaked at No. 12 on the UK Albums Chart, not managing to match the success of Stone's two previous albums. It nevertheless debuted at No. 2 on the ''Billboard'' 200 selling 118,000 copies in its first week,<ref>{{cite magazine |url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/1053393/modest-mouse-steers-its-ship-to-no-1-debut |title=Modest Mouse Steers Its 'Ship' To No. 1 Debut |access-date=30 April 2008 |last=Hasty |first=Katie |date=28 March 2007 |magazine=Billboard}}</ref> becoming the highest debut for a British solo female artist on the US chart, surpassing the record previously held by [[Amy Winehouse]] with ''[[Back to Black]]''<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mtv.co.uk/channel/mtvuk/news/29032007/joss_beats_winehouse |title=Joss Beats Winehouse |access-date=29 March 2007 |last=James |first=Sarah-Louise |date=29 March 2007 |work=[[MTV UK and Ireland|MTV UK]]}}</ref> (which in turn would later be outdone by [[Leona Lewis]], whose album ''[[Spirit (Leona Lewis album)|Spirit]]'' debuted at No. 1 the week of 26 April 2008).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.eonline.com/news/article/index.jsp?uuid=f740df1e-f0b0-4ace-8777-a06238236cd5 |title=That's the ''Spirit''! Leona Lewis' Historic No. 1 |access-date=20 April 2008 |last=Jenison |first=David |date=16 April 2008 |work=[[E! News]]}}</ref>

"[[Tell Me 'Bout It]]", the album's lead single, debuted and peaked at No. 28 on the UK Singles Chart. The second single, "[[Tell Me What We're Gonna Do Now]]", a collaboration with rapper Common, failed to chart inside the UK top seventy-five.{{citation needed|date=August 2016}} Stone and Common turned the single's music video into a [[Product Red]], reverting 100% of the gains from copies of the video purchased from iTunes to [[the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria]]. Stone is the first Product Red artist to do so.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.joinred.com/news/ |title=Joss Stone and Common turn (RED) |access-date=13 July 2007 |work=[[Product Red]] |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070704123752/http://www.joinred.com/news/ |archive-date= 4 July 2007}}</ref> Stone also sampled Franklin's "[[Respect (song)|Respect]]", taking the texture and sound of the song, but keeping her own composition.<ref>{{cite book |last=Schloss|first=Joseph |date=2004 |title=Making Beats: The Art of Sample-Based Hip-Hop |url=https://archive.org/details/makingbeatsartof0000schl|url-access=registration|publisher=MIddletown:Wesleyan University Press |page=[https://archive.org/details/makingbeatsartof0000schl/page/164 164] |isbn=9780819566966}}</ref> "[[Baby Baby Baby (Joss Stone song)|Baby Baby Baby]]" was released digitally in December 2007 and physically in January 2008 as the third single. In support of the album, Stone embarked on a North American tour which began on 27 April at [[Foxwoods Resort Casino]] in [[Ledyard, Connecticut|Ledyard]], Connecticut and ended on 13 June at the Filene Center in [[Vienna, Virginia|Vienna]], Virginia, visiting sixteen cities in total including Philadelphia, San Francisco, Vancouver, Chicago, Toronto, New York and Boston.<ref>{{cite magazine |url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/1054121/joss-stone-reintroducing-herself-on-tour |title=Joss Stone Reintroducing Herself on Tour |access-date=5 November 2007 |last=Cohen |first=Jonathan |date=8 March 2007 |magazine=Billboard}}</ref> Two months later, she went on a North American late-summer tour which kicked off on 27 August at the [[Greek Theatre (Los Angeles)|Greek Theatre]] in Los Angeles and ended on 29 September at the Crossroads in Kansas City, Missouri, covering twelve cities—this time including Mexico City.<ref>{{cite magazine |url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/1051739/joss-stone-solidifies-late-summer-tour |title=Joss Stone Solidifies Late Summer Tour |access-date=5 November 2007 |last=Cohen |first=Jonathan |date=4 June 2007 |magazine=Billboard}}</ref>

===2009–2010: ''Colour Me Free!'' and departure from EMI===
[[File:Joss Stone @ Stockholm jazz fest 01 new.jpg|thumb|right|upright|Stone at the [[Stockholm Jazz Festival]] in 2009]]
Stone was photographed by Canadian singer-guitarist and photographer [[Bryan Adams]] for [[Phonak]]'s ''Hear the World'' initiative, whose main goal is to raise global awareness for the topic of [[Hearing (sense)|hearing]] and [[Hearing impairment|hearing loss]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hear-the-world.com/botschafter/botschafter_joss.htm |title=Joss Stone on ''Hear the World'' |access-date=18 April 2007 |work=Hear the World |archive-url =https://web.archive.org/web/20080215215518/http://www.hear-the-world.com/botschafter/botschafter_joss.htm <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archive-date = 15 February 2008}}</ref> On 7 July 2007, Stone performed at the [[Live Earth concert, Johannesburg|South African leg]] of the [[Live Earth]] concerts at the [[Coca-Cola Dome]] in [[Johannesburg]], to promote awareness of [[global warming]]. She sang the ''Introducing Joss Stone'' tracks "Girl They Won't Believe It", "Headturner", "Tell Me What We're Gonna Do Now", "Music", and "Tell Me 'bout It", as well as ''Mind, Body & Soul'''s "Right to Be Wrong" and "Gimme Shelter", the latter with [[Angélique Kidjo]]. Stone covered [[Nat King Cole]]'s 1965 song "[[L-O-V-E]]" for an advertising campaign for [[Chanel]]'s [[Coco Mademoiselle]] fragrance.{{citation needed|date=February 2021}}

On 29 November 2007, Stone joined [[Jeff Beck]] on a duet of [[the Impressions]]'s 1965 song "[[People Get Ready (song)|People Get Ready]]" as part of his series of concerts at London's [[Ronnie Scott's Jazz Club]], documented on the DVD ''Performing This Week: Live at Ronnie Scott's''. To raise the awareness of AIDS, [[Annie Lennox]] joined forces with twenty-three female acts (including Stone) and recorded the song "[[Sing (Annie Lennox song)|Sing]]", which was released on [[World AIDS Day]] on 1 December 2007, when Lennox performed at one of [[Nelson Mandela]]'s [[46664 (concerts)|46664 concerts]] at [[Johannesburg]]'s [[Ellis Park Stadium]]. In mid-December 2007, Stone was named the new [[Flake (chocolate)|Flake]] girl to star in a series of television adverts for the [[Cadbury Schweppes]] product in the spring of 2008. According to the company, she is the first non-model to take the role.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/devon/7146879.stm |title=Singer Stone is new Flake girl |access-date=17 December 2007 |date=16 December 2007 |publisher=BBC News | location=London}}</ref>

In March 2008, Stone landed the role of lesbian [[bingo caller]] Stephanie in the British romantic comedy film ''Snappers'', for which she also wrote music.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://metro.co.uk/2008/03/27/josss-lesbian-kiss-in-movie-role-54750/ |title=Joss's lesbian kiss in movie role |work=[[Metro (British newspaper)|Metro]] |date=27 March 2008 |access-date=19 December 2017}}</ref> However, the film was never released.<ref>{{cite web |last=Kinser |first=Jeremy |url=https://www.advocate.com/arts-entertainment/entertainment-news/2011/10/14/joss-stone-ricky-martin-and-kissing-girls |title=Joss Stone On Ricky Martin and Kissing Girls |work=[[The Advocate (LGBT magazine)|Advocate]] |date=14 October 2011 |access-date=19 December 2017}}</ref> Stone made her television debut portraying [[Henry VIII of England|Henry VIII]]'s fourth wife [[Anne of Cleves]] in the third season of the [[Showtime (TV network)|Showtime]] series ''[[The Tudors]]''.<ref name="tudors"/> She reprised the role in the show's final season in 2010,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tvsquad.com/2009/05/12/joss-stone-agrees-to-return-for-the-tudors-final-season/ |title=Joss Stone agrees to return for The Tudors final season |access-date=14 July 2009 |last=Hughes |first=Jason |date=12 May 2009 |work=TV Squad}}</ref> appearing in two episodes.

Stone launched a legal battle in a bid to leave her record label, [[EMI]], and free her of her current three-album deal with the record label in April 2008.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.starpulse.com/news/index.php/2008/04/21/joss_stone_begins_battle_to_leave_emi/ |title=Joss Stone Begins Battle To Leave EMI |access-date=25 April 2008 |date=21 April 2008 |work=Starpulse |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080424075428/http://www.starpulse.com/news/index.php/2008/04/21/joss_stone_begins_battle_to_leave_emi |archive-date=24 April 2008}}</ref> Stone performed at the 19th Annual [[GLAAD Media Awards]] at the [[Kodak Theatre]] in Hollywood, Los Angeles on 26 April 2008.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.glaad.org/mediaawards/19thAnnual/LAAwardsPost.php |title=19th Annual GLAAD Media Awards – Los Angeles, April 26, 2008 |access-date=5 July 2008 |work=[[Gay & Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation|GLAAD]] |archive-url =https://web.archive.org/web/20080614195806/http://www.glaad.org/mediaawards/19thAnnual/LAAwardsPost.php <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archive-date = 14 June web |url=http://nationalgaynews.com/content/view/3689/173/ |title=LA Pride Entertainment |access-date=13 June 2008 |date=1 June 2008 |publisher=NationalGayNews.com |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081208162325/http://nationalgaynews.com/content/view/3689/173/ |archive-date=8 December 2008}}</ref> On 26 October 2008, Stone sang the British national anthem, "[[God Save the Queen]]", before the [[2008 NFL season|NFL]] match between the [[San Diego Chargers]] and the [[New Orleans Saints]], held at [[Wembley Stadium]] in London.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.daylife.com/photo/0d9Lbi8axU41a |title=Photo from Getty Images – Daylife |access-date=3 November 2008 |date=26 October 2008 |work=[[Daylife]] |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081208090629/http://www.daylife.com/photo/0d9Lbi8axU41a |archive-date=8 December 2008}}</ref>

[[File:Joss Stone HagenU.jpg|thumb|right|upright|Stone performing during a festival, as part of the Colour Me Free! World Tour]]
On 7 December 2008, Stone performed [[the Who]]'s 1965 song "[[My Generation (The Who song)|My Generation]]" on [[CBS]]'s [[Kennedy Center Honors]] TV special at the [[John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts|Kennedy Center]], Washington, D.C., honouring [[Pete Townshend]] and [[Roger Daltrey]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dallasnews.com/sharedcontent/dws/ent/stories/DN-kennedy_1230gd.ART.State.Edition1.4a528ae.html |title=Kennedy Center honors six classics |access-date=1 January 2009 |last=Boedeker |first=Hal |date=30 December 2008 |work=[[The Dallas Morning News]]}}</ref> In 2010, Stone also appeared on [[Ringo Starr]]'s album, ''Y Not'' on the song "Who's Your Daddy" in which she sang and co-wrote with the ex-Beatle; appeared on Jeff Beck's album, ''Emotion and Commotion'' on the songs "There's No Other Me" and "[[I Put a Spell on You]]", being the last one nominated for the [[Grammy Award for Best Rock Performance by a Duo or Group with Vocal]] at [[53rd Grammy Awards]]. In late 2010, Stone's voice and likeness were used for the "[[Bond girl]]" character of Nicole Hunter, a jewellery designer and MI6 agent, in the video game ''[[James Bond 007: Blood Stone]]''. In addition to portraying the character, she also performed the game's theme song, "I'll Take It All", which was co-written and performed with [[David A. Stewart|Dave Stewart]].

In 2010, Stone provided vocals on two songs for the charity-focused audio drama production, ''A Voyage For Soldier Miles''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.soldiermiles.com|title=A Voyage For Soldier Miles|website=Soldiermiles.com|access-date=14 February 2021}}</ref> The songs are "Lover Earth" written by [[David A. Stewart|Dave Stewart]] and [[Mark Warford]] and "Never Gonna Be The Same" written and performed by [[Mark Warford]] and Niels Lan Doky.

Stone's fourth studio album was written and recorded in about a week in Devon in early 2008. She said: "It's very, very raw. It's a bunch of musicians, writers and myself, and we're just jamming, basically."<ref name="newalbum">{{cite magazine |url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/1043594/joss-stone-rocks-the-vote-with-new-song |title=Joss Stone Rocks The Vote With New Song |access-date=5 November 2008 |last=Peters |first=Mitchell |date=4 November 2008 |magazine=Billboard}}</ref> In promotion of the album, entitled ''[[Colour Me Free!]]'', Stone played concerts throughout the UK in February and March.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://jossstone.echoconnect.com/ |title=Joss Stone : Home |access-date=19 February 2009 |work=jossstone.echoconnect.com |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090307063623/http://jossstone.echoconnect.com/ |archive-date= 7 March 2009}}</ref> Originally scheduled for release in April 2009, ''[[Colour Me Free!]]'' was finally released on 20 October 2009. Stone said that her record company also fought her about the original cover of her new album, calling it "offensive". It was changed to simple text and no picture of Stonebon the American edition, the original cover was used on the other editions worldwide. In late August 2010, it was reported that Stone had left EMI<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.jossstone.com/forum/index.php?topic=1177.0 |title=downloads |access-date=26 August 2010 |publisher=jossstone.com |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110713121338/http://www.jossstone.com/forum/index.php?topic=1177.0 |archive-date=13 July 2011}}</ref> and formed her own independent record label, [[Stone'd Records]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.stoned-records.com/ |title=Stone'd Records | Joss Stone |publisher=Stoned-records.com |access-date=4 June 2014}}</ref> EMI announced in late December that they would be releasing a greatest hits album, ''[[The Best of Joss Stone 2003–2009]]''. The compilation was released on 30 September 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.de/dp/B004G6OFC8 |title=The Best of Joss Stone 2003–2009: Amazon.de: Musik |website=Amazon Germany |access-date=4 June 2014}}</ref>

In 2010, Stone collaborated with [[Puerto Rico|Puerto Rican]] recording artist [[Ricky Martin]] for "[[The Best Thing About Me Is You]]", and peaked at No. 74 on the U.S [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]] and which topped the ''Hot Latin Songs'' and ''Latin Pop Songs'' chart, this was Stone's first number-one on all two charts, which also made her the first Briton of non-Hispanic origin to reach No. 1 on the ''Hot Latin Tracks'' and ''Latin Pop Songs'' chart.

===2011–2018: ''LP1'', ''The Soul Sessions Vol. 2'' and ''Water for Your Soul''===
[[File:Joss Stone Tom Brasil (44386659660).jpg|thumb|180px|left|Stone performing in [[São Paulo, Brazil]], December 2018]]
On 14 June 2011, police arrested two men in [[Cullompton]], Devon, near Stone's home, for plotting to rob and murder her.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.express.co.uk/posts/view/252876/Two-men-arrested-over-plot-to-rob-and-murder-Joss-Stone |title=Two men arrested over plot to 'rob and murder' Joss Stone | Showbiz  |work=Daily Express |date=15 June 2011 |access-date=4 June 2014}}</ref> After a trial at [[Exeter]] [[Crown Court]] for conspiracy to rob, murder and commit grievous bodily harm against her, they were found guilty and convicted on 3 April 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-22013160 |title=Joss Stone death plot: Junior Bradshaw and Kevin Liverpool convicted |publisher=BBC |date=3 April 2013 |access-date=4 June 2014}}</ref>

Stone partnered with [[Surfdog Records]] to release ''[[LP1 (Joss Stone album)|LP1]]'' on 26 July 2011, through her own label Stone'd Records.<ref name="off">{{cite web|url=http://www.jossstone.com/articles.html?n_id=4667|title=Joss Stone Announces Release of New Album, LP1, on July 26|publisher=JossStone.com|date=5 May 2011|access-date=24 May 2011|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120620141807/http://www.jossstone.com/articles.html?n_id=4667|archive-date=20 June 2012}}</ref> The album was recorded in [[Nashville, Tennessee]] in six days, where Stone co-wrote and co-produced the album with [[Eurythmics]] co-founder, [[David A. Stewart|David Stewart]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://theaudioperv.com/2011/05/05/joss-stone-announces-new-album-lp1-due-out-july-26/ |title=Joss Stone Announces New Album LP1 Due Out July 26 |publisher=The Audio Perv |access-date=4 June 2014}}</ref> The lead single, "[[Somehow (Joss Stone song)|Somehow]]", was released on 24 June 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/music/news/a324224/joss-stone-unveils-new-single-somehow.html |title=Joss Stone unveils new single 'Somehow' – Music News |work=Digital Spy |date=10 June 2011 |access-date=4 June 2014}}</ref> Stone also joined the supergroup [[SuperHeavy]] which was formed by [[Mick Jagger]] of the [[Rolling Stones]], together with [[David A. Stewart|Dave Stewart]] (credited by Mick with the original idea of SuperHeavy), [[Damian Marley]] (the youngest son of [[Bob Marley]]) and the Indian musician and producer [[A.R. Rahman]].<ref>{{cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/mick-jagger-forms-supergroup-with-dave-stewart-joss-stone-and-damian-marley-20110520 |title=Mick Jagger Forms Supergroup with Dave Stewart, Joss Stone and Damian Marley |first=Andy |last=Greene |magazine=Rolling Stone |date=20 May 2011 |access-date=22 May 2011}}</ref> The album was recorded at [[Jim Henson Studios]] in Los Angeles and was released on 20 September 2011 by [[A&M Records]]. The debut single, "Miracle Worker", was released on 19 July 2011.

Released in July 2012, ''[[The Soul Sessions Vol. 2]]'' saw Stone return to her original label, [[S-Curve Records]], who released the album jointly with the artist's Stone'd Records, and features production from [[Steve Greenberg (record producer)|Steve Greenberg]] (producer of the first "Soul Sessions"). ==Artistry==
Stone possesses the vocal range of a [[mezzo-soprano]] and [[contralto]].<ref>{{cite news| url = https://www.seattlepi.com/lifestyle/blogcritics/article/Music-Review-Joss-Stone-The-Best-of-Joss-2208568.php| title = Music Review: Joss Stone - The Best of Joss Stone: 2003-2009| work=seattlepi.com| date=7 October 2011| access-date=2 July 2019| first=Jordan| last=Richardson}}</ref> She often performs barefoot and has been described as "the white [[Aretha Franklin]]" since her debut in music industry.<ref>{{cite news|first=Polly |last=Vernon |url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2004/jan/18/popandrock.shopping1 |title=Joss Stone: the barefoot diva | The Observer |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |access-date=4 June 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/music/music-news/8576782/Joss-Stone-the-white-Aretha-Franklin-of-soul.html|title=Joss Stone: the 'white Aretha Franklin' of soul|first=Andrew|last=Hough|date=15 June 2011|access-date=17 May 2018|website=Telegraph.co.uk}}</ref><ref name="theguardian.com">{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2003/nov/14/popandrock1|title=Is Joss Stone the new Aretha Franklin?|first=Alexis|last=Petridis|date=14 November 2003|website=The Guardian|access-date=17 May 2018}}</ref> However, Stone was the subject of some contention in the United States, according to [[Alexis Petridis]], writing in ''The Guardian'' in 2003, where, he claims, her audience expected soul artists "to have been born in poverty and have had a rough and painful life" in order to sing soul music due to its emotional nature.<ref name="theguardian.com"/>

==Personal life==
In 2004, Stone began dating Beau Dozier, with whom she co-wrote the song "Spoiled". Dozier is the son of Motown producer [[Lamont Dozier]], who is best known as part of [[Holland-Dozier-Holland]]. The couple ended their relationship in November 2005.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-138961585.html|archive-url=https://archive.today/20120526224745/http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-138961585.html|url-status=dead|archive-date=26 May 2012|title=Joss tells of broken heart over love split|access-date=7 June 2008|date=21 November 2005|newspaper=[[London Evening Standard]]}}</ref>

In a 2016 interview, Stone revealed that she had been in a relationship with music promoter SiChai for three years.<ref>{{cite news|first=Katie |last=Law |url=https://www.standard.co.uk/showbiz/celebrity-news/joss-stone-talks-freezing-her-eggs-reverse-racism-and-being-pals-with-prince-harry-a3188951.html |title=Joss Stone talks freezing her eggs, reverse racism and being pals with Prince Harry |newspaper=[[London Evening Standard]] |date=25 February 2016 |access-date=23 July 2017}}</ref>

Stone is a lifelong [[vegetarian]], and has taken part in various campaigns for animal rights group [[PETA]]. Stone owns a number of [[rescue dogs]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.fromthegrapevine.com/arts/5-things-you-didnt-know-about-joss-stone|title=5 things you didn't know about Joss Stone|website=From the Grapevine|access-date=20 October 2017}}</ref>

The Joss Stone Foundation ultimately supported more than 200 charities across the globe as Stone completed her world tour. The primary aim was to help raise public awareness and support for these charities.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://jossstone.com/|title=The Official Website of Joss Stone|website=JossStone.com|access-date=14 February 2021}}</ref>

In September 2020, Stone announced via [[Instagram]] that she was pregnant with her first child with boyfriend Cody DaLuz.<ref>{{cite web|last=Juneau|first=Jen|date=5 October 2020|url=https://people.com/parents/joss-stone-pregnant-expecting-first-child-boyfriend-cody-daluz/|title=Joss Stone Expecting First Child After Months of Trying to Conceive: 'Don't Give' Up|work=[[People (magazine)|People]]|access-date=}}</ref> She gave birth to a daughter on 29 January 2021.<ref>{{cite web |last=Cardoza |first=Riley |date=1 February 2021 |url=https://www.usmagazine.com/celebrity-moms/news/joss-stone-gives-birth-welcomes-1st-child-with-boyfriend-cody-daluz/ |title=New Mom!
